title: Chapter 7 Statement of Intentions...What if I change my mind and don't want to reaffirm my car and/or home?
question: I am in the Central district of California. I am wondering what the effect is if I decide NOT to reaffirm my car and/or mortgage after having stated my intention to reaffirm? MUST I amend the statement of intentions? Also, is there any binding effect because I said I wanted to keep and reaffirm? Someone told me mortgages never bother to send out reaffirmation documents anyway...would that mean I would be off the hook in the future for any future deficiencies if I kept the house and then later fell into default? Why don't they send them? Will changing my mind hold up my discharge at all? Sorry for the multiple questions, but I do greatly appreciate the advice.
answers:
You can only reaffirm a debt by entering into an agreement before discharge and having that agreement entered into the court record. You can always voluntarily make payments post filing. That in no way reaffirms the debt.

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

The Statement of Intention is a required document. It must be filed. Failure to comply with it just means that the Automatic Stay ends early. However, if your jurisdiction follows the same interpretation as this one does (Eastern District of Virginia), then no reaffirmation agreement is required for real estate AND if the creditor does not send out a reaffirmation agreement for a vehicle, then you have complied with the law. So long as the payments are current and the vehicle is insured you are protected. Furthermore, if your state does not allow the so-called ipso facto clause (filing bankruptcy is a breach of contract), then you also have nothing to worry about.

Talk to your attorney for a full explanation of the Statement and its impact on your case.

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

It's just that - a statement of intent. The code technically requires the debtor to perform in accordance with the statement of intention within a certain period of time, but I have seen cases that do not bind the debtor to the stated intention.

Generally speaking, I almost never have a client reaffirm a home, as they can keep the home without reaffirming the debt. The lender on your vehicle may require a reaffirmation for you to keep the car. I think there is an argument under state law that reaffirmation is not a requirement for a vehicle, but that is getting a little too technical for this question. Despite what you were told, lenders on homes and vehicles regularly send me reaffirmation agreements. Whether we sign them is another issue.

If you continued to pay on the house without reaffirming (ofter referred to as "retain and pay"), and you defaulted in the future, your discharge would protect you from the deficiency. If you refinance or sign a new contract with any lender in the future, however, that protection against a deficiency will be lost because you now have personal liability again.

It can only help you to amend your statement of intention and serve it on the affected creditors. Lots of issues and questions here. Since I don't know everything about your case, I can only generalize and can't say what are the appropriate choices for you to make. Definitely seek the advice of competent counsel in you area. Good luck.

This information is not, nor is it intended to be, legal advice. This does not constitute the formation of an attorney-client relationship. You should consult an attorney for individual advice regarding the specifics of your situation. JC Law Group is a debt relief agency. We help people find relief by filing bankruptcy in California under the Bankruptcy Code.

In my opinion, you don't have to amend the Statement of Intention. You can just leave it the way it is.

That's because what really matters here is that if you don't want to reaffirm a debt, whether it's for a car or your home, then just don't sign the reaffirmation agreement. Even if your Statement of Intention states that your intent is to re-affirm a debt, you don't have a re-affirmed debt if you don't sign a reaffirmation agreement.

So if you don't reaffirm a mortgage, then you're correct -- you would be off the hook in the future for any deficiencies if you kept the house and then later fell into default.

Changing your mind regarding your Statement of Intention does not hold up the order of discharge.

Whether or not a mortgage lender will send you a reaffirmation agreement depends on your circumstances. The lender in first position might not bother, because the lender is in first position. If you go into default, post-bankruptcy, the lender will just sell your house at a foreclosure sale. The lender in second position might send you a reaffirmation agreement, and allege that if you want to negotiate a loan modification, then the lender wants you to reaffirm the loan.

These kind of issues need to be discussed with an attorney. The usual practice in California is that debtors don't reaffirm mortgages, because reaffirming a mortgage makes you personally liable for that mortgage. So if a lender does send you a reaffirmation agreement, don't just sign it. Take it to an attorney for review.
